item.title: Using Git with multiple accounts on one system

item.content:
Set correct E-Mail address based on directory

Git supports conditional configurations, let’s take advantage of this. Assuming we have an account for Github and Azure, we create a directory for each provider where we clone the repositories.

PS C:\Dev> New-Item -Name 'AzRepos' -Type Directory
PS C:\Dev> New-Item -Name 'ghRepos' -Type Directory

For each directory we need a configuration file. These files should be located near the git config file. On Windows the config file are located at the user dirctory. So we creat two files, .gitconfig-azure and .gitconfig-github.

PS C:\Users\t0rsten> New-Item -Name '.gitconfig-azure' -Type File
PS C:\Users\t0rsten> New-Item -Name '.gitconfig-github' -Type File

At the corresponding files we insert name and email adresse like this:

[user]
    name = jane
    email = jane@exampl.com

At the .gifconfig, were is located at the user directory, now remove the existing [user] configuration and add the conditional configuration. The includeIf conditional configuration set these settings by loading configurations from the files.

[includeIf "gitdir/i:C:/Dev/AzRepos/"]
	path = .gitconfig-azure
	
[includeIf "gitdir/i:C:/Dev/ghRepos/"]
	path = .gitconfig-github

The conditional import will automatically switch to the correct name and email.

item.title: [PS Snippet] Test-Path vs. Resolve-Path
item.description: Test-Path will check if the path exist or not and return a Boolean output. Resolve-Path shows the given directory if it exists, otherwise an exception is thrown. Test-Path -Path 'C:\Temp' True Resolve-Path -Path 'C:\Temp1\' Resolve-Path : Cannot find path 'C:\Temp1\' because it does not exist. At line:1 char:1 + Resolve-Path -Path 'C:\Temp1\' + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ + CategoryInfo : ObjectNotFound: (C:\Temp1\:String) [Resolve-Path], ItemNotFoundException + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ResolvePathCommand Wildcards can be used with Resolve-Path as well.
item.content:
Test-Path will check if the path exist or not and return a Boolean output. Resolve-Path shows the given directory if it exists, otherwise an exception is thrown.

Test-Path -Path 'C:\Temp'
True

Resolve-Path -Path 'C:\Temp1\'

Resolve-Path : Cannot find path 'C:\Temp1\' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Resolve-Path -Path 'C:\Temp1\'
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (C:\Temp1\:String) [Resolve-Path], ItemNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ResolvePathCommand

Wildcards can be used with Resolve-Path as well.

Resolve-Path -Path 'C:\Windows\Logs\*'

Path
----
C:\Windows\Logs\CBS
C:\Windows\Logs\DISM
C:\Windows\Logs\DPX
C:\Windows\Logs\MeasuredBoot
C:\Windows\Logs\MoSetup
C:\Windows\Logs\NetSetup
C:\Windows\Logs\SIH
C:\Windows\Logs\SystemRestore
C:\Windows\Logs\waasmedic
C:\Windows\Logs\WindowsUpdate

item.title: [PS Snippet] Find Last Reboot
item.description: Find the last reboot. Get-EventLog -LogName System -ComputerName $Env:COMPUTERNAME | Where-Object { $_.eventid -eq '1074' } | sort -Descending -Property timegenerated | Select-Object -First 1 -Property MachineName, Username, timegenerate
item.content:
Find the last reboot.

Get-EventLog -LogName System -ComputerName $Env:COMPUTERNAME | Where-Object { $_.eventid -eq '1074' } | sort -Descending -Property timegenerated | Select-Object -First 1 -Property MachineName, Username, timegenerate

item.title: [PS Snippet] Difference Between Break and Continue
item.description: The difference between break and continue. break exit a loop or switch statement. continue continue but skips the current iteration. switch (2,4,5) { 1 {"One"} 2 {"Two"; continue} 3 {"Three"} 4 {"Four"; break} 5 {"Five"} } Output Two Four
item.content:
The difference between break and continue.

  • break exit a loop or switch statement.
  • continue continue but skips the current iteration.
switch (2,4,5)
{
  1 {"One"}
  2 {"Two"; continue}
  3 {"Three"}
  4 {"Four"; break}
  5 {"Five"}
}

Output

Two
Four
